newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian Broadcasting Corp Morning Update.
newsitem.headline: Australian Broadcasting Corp Morning Update.

text.p: NATIONAL HOLIDAY ROAD TOLL AT 16
The national road toll for the Easter holiday period stands at 16.
The number of fatalities is lower than last year's national toll of 28.
Western Australia and Victoria had the highest number of fatal crashes with four deaths each.
Three people died on New South Wales roads, and two each in
Queensland and the Northern Territory.
South Australia had one death, Tasmania and the ACT were fatality free.
VICTIMS RIGHTS BILL AMENDMENT
in New South Wales, the Shooters Party's John Tingle is confident his amendment to the Victims Rights Bill won't lead to uncertainty among the judiciary.
The amendment, due to become law on Wednesday, requires judges in murder cases to hear and acknowledge a Family Impact Statement during sentencing.
Director of Public Prosecutions, Nicholas Cowdery Q-C, has raised concerns about the effect and interpretation of the amendment.
Mr Tingle says it's clear that judges are not forced to take the impact statement into account.
SHEARING INDUSTRY CODE FOCUSES ON HEAT STRESS
Acceptable temperatures for working in shearing sheds may be included in a proposed code-of-practice for the shearing industry.
The Australian Workers Union has launched the code, which it says aims to protect shearers from occupational health risks.
Yossi Berger, from the AWU's Workplace Health and Safety Section, says the code also restricts use of chemicals and seeks to improve work-place design, to reduce injury.
Dr Berger says while the union is looking at heat stress as a health risk across many occupations, it's an area of particular concern for shearers.
FOSTERS A TOP-SELLER IN LONDON
Fosters Brewing says its beer is now the top-seller in London.
The company sells around one million pints of beer in Britain every day.
Television commercials featuring comedians H.G. and Roy are said to have led to a 10 per cent increase in sales since December.
The commercials are said to emphasise the benefits of a "laid-back Australian attitude, and an enjoyable beer, in a stressful world."
CAR PRODUCERS GET MOST OUT OF TARIFFS: CHAMBER
The West Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry says car producers are the big winners out of Australia's high vehicle tariffs.
The chamber's chief economist, Nicki Cusworth says it's unacceptable that in 1995 tariffs can be shown to have cost new car buyers almost four-thousand dollars per vehicle.
The tariff on imported cars is currently 25 per cent, and this is set to fall to 15 per cent in the Year two-thousand.
But the chamber says it strongly supports the Industry Commission's Draft Report on the Automotive Industry, which advocates further phased reductions in tariffs to five percent.
LOST WOMAN AND CHILDREN FOUND IN GOOD HEALTH
West Australian police say a woman and 13 children are all in good health, after being lost for two days in the State's goldfields.

A trip to Bromus Dam, south of Norseman in W.A's south-east, turned into trouble for the group on Saturday when their 1976 station-wagon broke down in bush, more than 25-kilometres from the Norseman-Esperance road.
Six of the children walked more than 30-kilometres in the direction of the road before they were found by the search party this afternoon.
Mrs Schultz and the other seven children were located a short time later.
Their rescue followed a widescale search involving three planes, police, the State Emergency Service, and relatives of the missing people.
Police say the 14 people are healthy despite their two-day ordeal.
BUDDHIST TEMPLE AND UNI PLANNED
In New South Wales, a A$500 million dollar Buddhist temple and university is being planned for a site west of Shellharbour, just south of Wollongong.
A Chinese Buddhist group is understood to have bought 180 hectares of land on the Illawarra escarpment at Yellowrock, and is negotiating to buy another 60 hectares.
A delegation recently met with Shellharbour Council to discuss its plans, but no development application has yet been presented.
NO SIGN OF MISSING MEN
In Tasmania, police have switched the focus of their search for three men missing since yesterday in rugged terrain west of Hobart.
The three left New Norfolk at 10.30 a.m. yesterday to drive the Jeffreys Track to Judbury.
Searchers in two four-wheel drives this morning drove the length of the track from Lachlan, but found no sign of the men or their vehicle.
Acting Sergeant Michael Barber says they are now re-evaluating their options.
POLICE DOORKNOCK HOMES IN MACKAY MURDER HUNT
Mackay police are conducting a doorknock this morning in a hunt for clues to a fatal shooting in the north Queensland city last night.
Police say a 46-year-old man was shot in the back while attempting to flee from an intruder he disturbed in his backyard about 8.15 last night.
